title: In US v. California, will the District Court grant any preliminary injunctions against enforcement of California's sanctuary laws"?
possible_answers: Yes, against two or more of the bills
preds: 450 seems like the most likely to be overturned but 103 also seems weak, so two or more seems like the most likely outcome.  Otherwise I can see the court saying that there's no harm an injunction would be preventing and denying it entirely.

Will Judge Mendez issue injunctions by the end of this month?
I wonder first about the timing, second, which bill or bills upon will he rest his decision knowing the case will be appealed, and third, how does the Judge view his role in this very high profile case?
Dont see why he might hurry to decide but I'll assign 20% to that unknown (to me) of how he decides his role in this case post SCOTUS decisions for 2018 and before midterm elections. Judge Mendez was appointed by George W. Bush in 2008.

As a localist I am trapped by my philosophy on this one. I like power decentralized to the lowest practical unit and support any citys right to be idiots. SCOTUS has shown some renewed support for State Sovereignty, and this case tests how far down the chain they will go in supporting localist theory...accidentally or otherwise.

Precedent and also President Trump has a poor relationship with this particular Court: https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/1/10/16873718/ninth-circuit-court-appeals-liberal-conservative-trump-tweet
Shifting toward no because the courts work slowly, also legal reasons I suppose.
If not signed into law, the issue is moot.

The Judge in the Philadelphia case went further than I thought. He cited the recent Supreme Court decision in Murphy v. NCAA that the federal government cannot tell local or state governments that they can't pass certain laws which calls into question the constitutionality of the federal law being used by Trump/Sessions (Code 1373 of the INA) on which their case rests.  US Code 1373 of the Immigration and Nationality Act requires that state and local governments transmit information about individuals' immigration status to the federal government if asked, and that no state or local governments or officials can prohibit doing so which means that states and local governments cannot pass laws that accomplish just that. The judge wrote that the Supreme Court found that the federal government could not prohibit states from passing certain laws.
"Because Section 1373 directly tells states and state actors that they must refrain from enacting certain state laws, it is unconstitutional under the Tenth Amendment," Baylson wrote. http://joshblackman.com/blog/2017/04/21/sanctuary-cities-and-the-constitutionality-of-8-u-s-c-1373/ At this point, I believe the CA case will take longer making it unlikely that an injunction will be granted in less than six months.

AB450 prohibits private employers from voluntarily cooperating with federal immigration enforcement efforts and 
AB103 creates inspection and review of due process of federal immigration enforcement efforts 
These two may be viewed as overreach and obstacles to federal efforts to enforce. This question covers preliminary injunctions of any aspect of these laws which raises the possibility of Judge Mendez doing that for some piece of those laws.

I am going hard toward no simply because I was burned last time on this question for assuming the court system would move faster. Going to assume this time that the gears of justice turn slowly and we will get the same result. That being said, just in case the court finally get around to a ruling, I think AB 450 is the weakest of the three laws and is the mostly likely to be targeted by a judge. Unless of course a judge decided to grant a preliminary injunction against the wider effort in California.
Federal Court in Philadelphia ruled against the administration in a similar case yesterday.
